thread.title: Best cash Isa 'Nisa' rates

author: Kyle Caldwell
title: Best cash Isa 'Nisa' rates
text: Savers can now put up to £15,240 in a cash Isa for the 2015-16 tax year. Here, we name the top fixed-rate cash Isas (where your money is locked into a specified rate for the whole term) and the top easy-access Isas (where the rate is variable, but you can access your money as many times as you want). Bookmark this page – updated on a regular basis – for the latest Isa deals or opt for our weekly money round-up . Don't forget that there are alternative accounts that could pay more on your savings pot, such as high-paying current accounts. See our favourites here . BEST FIXED-RATE DEALS ONE YEAR: Tesco Bank, Holmesdale Building Society, Shawbrook Bank and Julian Hodge bank all pay 1.75pc. TWO YEARS: Virgin Money pays 2pc on balances above £1, with old Isa money accepted and interest paid annually or monthly. Skipton, Principality and Halifax also pay 2pc , but the mimumum investment is higher at £500. THREE YEARS: Leeds Building Society pays a top rate of 2.3pc. It can be opened in branch, by post or online and it accepts transfers from old Isas. FOUR YEARS: The best four-year account on the market is offered by Julian Hodge Bank , paying 2.15pc . The account can be opened by post, and it does accept old Isa money. A minimum deposit of £5,000 is required. FIVE YEARS: Welsh bank Julian Hodge pays 2.55pc. The account must be opened by post, while the minimum investment stands at £5,000. Transfers in from previous years' Isas are accepted. BEST EASY-ACCESS DEALS [NOTICE ACCOUNT] Secure Trust pay 2.05pc on deposits above £1,000. Withdrawals are subject to 183 days notice or loss of interest. RCI Bank's Freedom Savings Account pays 1.65pc from £100. Interest is paid annually or monthly. Nationwide's "Flexclusive Isa" (issue 9) pays 1.6pc on balances above £1. Savers must also hold a "Flex" current account. Transfers in allowed, and the account is available online or in branch. National Savings & Investments (NS&I) is paying 1.5pc with no withdrawal restrictions. The "Direct Isa" needs an opening deposit of £1, but does not accept transfers in from other providers.
